Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Adaptive signal representation for accelerated multidimensional imaging

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The acquisition of high resolution multi-dimensional image data is becoming increasingly important in several bio-medical applications (e.g., spectroscopic imaging and cardiac imaging). Very often, imaging devices are pushed to their limits in the quest for high spatio-temporal/spatial-spectral resolution, resulting in several artifacts and SNR loss. Recently, the recovery of the image data from sub-Nyquist sampled measurements using constrained image models has emerged as a promising alternative. A challenge in using pre-determined models is the misfit between the representation and dataset; many coefficients are often required to represent the signal at hand. The main focus of this work is to develop a novel theoretical framework and efficient algorithms to adapt image representations to under-sampled measurements.

We specifically focus on blind or adaptive representations, which are a significant departure from classical approaches based on pre-determined dictionaries. By adapting the signal model to measurements, we expect to obtain unbiased reconstructions from far smaller numbers of measurements. We formulate the joint estimation of the representation and the signal from the entire under-sampled data as a single optimization problem, where the criterion is only dependent on the recovered signal. This enables the development of efficient optimization algorithms, performance optimization using tailored cost functions, and determination of the conditions for perfect recovery. This approach is expected to considerably improve the resolution in several multi-dimensional imaging schemes, which will facilitate several basic science and clinical applications of very high significance; the proposed research is truly transformative. The impact of this work is strengthened by the sharing of software and data-sharing, integration of research and teaching, and well-designed out-reach program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main focus of the project was is on developing efficient adaptive image representations for the recovery of multidimensional MRI data from under sampled measurements. 

 

 

 

Blind linear models: We have introduced convex and non-convex low-rank algorithms for the recovery of dynamic and parametric MRI applications. For the first time in the literature, we have demonstrated the utility in combining sparsity priors along with low­rank penalty. Specifically, the degrees of freedom of the matrix that is low­rank and sparse is often much smaller than matrices that are only low­rank or sparse. This work has resulted in a new algorithm termed as k­t SLR, which provided quite significant improvements over existing methods. The MATLAB code, which is disseminated over the web, is now downloaded and used by several researchers working in image recovery. The initial paper in this direction as well as the freely distributed software is now widely used in the community. The initial paper, published in 2011 has over 200 citations. We have recently introduced theoretical guarantees for two-step based low-rank recovery algorithms, which also provides valuable insights on the tradeoffs associated with the two-step scheme, compared to single step convex/non-convex recovery. 

We have recently extended the blind linear models to blind compressed sensing. Similar to blind linear modeling, the dictionary basis functions and its sparse coefficients are estimated from the data itself. Since the number of non­orthogonal dictionary basis functions are often much larger than the rank of the dataset, this approach provides a richer representation than blind linear models. At the same time, the sparsity of the basis functions keep the number of degrees of freedom low, thus enabling the recovery from highly under­ sampled data. The application of blind compressed sensing schemes to MRI problems provides considerable reduction in spatiotemporal blurring. We are currently piloting the application of this scheme to clinical MRI.

Non-local smoothing algorithms: We have introduced a novel non­local regularization penalty for image regularization, which penalizes the robust distances between image patches. We have also shown that classical non-local regularization algorithms as the first iteration of a specific algorithm to solve the robust penalized likelihood optimization problem. Iterating this algorithm to convergence is seen to quite considerably improve image quality.  The novel approach enabled the use of non-local regularization to the recovery of image data from highly undersampled measurements. In addition, this observation also enabled the introduction of fast optimization algorithms to solve the problem. We have recently used this framework for implicit motion compensated recovery of dynamic MRI, which offers a significant improvement over current algorithms that rely on explicit motion compensation methods.

 

Manifold models: The grant also enabled us to develop novel algorithms that exploit the manifold structure of image data in free breathing and ungated cardiac MRI. In addition to considerably reducing the scan time, the free breathing imaging approach also enables the imaging of subjects with compromised pulmonary function, pediatric subjects, as well as obese subjects.
